Yeah learning to program and that is a fucking nightmare but if we're talking about bare bones video games that is a good way to get into making games; hell a lot of people started out making crap games.  A lot of people have video games in them, some even have every person that has made games in them.

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55ae4f406368721a20004865#post_55ae4f406368721a20004865
The biggest problem people seem to have when they try to make games is they go "I'm going to make a 1000 hour game with photorealistic graphics and all this and that" and no; it's not possible for a single person to do that.

A really bad habit people getting into gaming and in fact the game industry has picked up is they don't budget their time and they don't budget their money.

Let's say hypothetically you have no life, you don't need to worry about bills and you don't have a family life or school; even if you spend 18 hours a day for a entire year making a game you're not going to make a 1000 hour game with Crysis graphics or such.

Not knowing how to budget time and money is why dead space is dead, why bioshock is dead; people just don't know how to budget money or time.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55ae513a63687234ff000404#post_55ae513a63687234ff000404
Don't game makers usually work in teams?
topics.author: 52f0834d63687261cba90300

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55ae51e36368724f860008bd#post_55ae51e36368724f860008bd
Well obviously, but you get my point.

A lot of game companies and game franchises have died because the people they put in charge didn't know how to budget their time or money.

If you miss your deadline in video gaming that's a lot of money down the toilet cause often times those deadlines are chosen as optimal selling dates to encourage sales; not to mention the amount of money lost if it's a physical disc publishing; not to mention those extra hours.  If you go overbudget that's really fucking bad.



If anything I'd argue that companies and people in charge of game development having a nasty habit of not knowing how to budget their time, work or money is one of the reasons contributing to the rise of digital downloads.  If your game is on a physical disc if you miss your target date that's a shit ton of money down the drain superhard; I'm not talking a couple thousand dollars or that, I'm talking about potentially hundreds of thousands of dollars just flushed down the toilet overall cause if you miss your target date then all the companies that you sell through have to change their distribution and such, then the retailers have to as well; there's a lot of money money lost if you miss your target date.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
